Hand foot mouth disease: Coxsackie A virus
Kaposi varicelliform eruption: HSV-1 virus

questions.text: Identify incorrect match among the following.
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Chicken pox: HSV 2 virus

 

Option D:

 

Characteristics of Chickenpox/Varicella

 

  • Causative agent: Varicella zoster virus (NOT HSV-2 virus) (Option D)
  • Incubation Period: 10-21 days
  • Infectious period: 2 days before the rash develops till all the lesions have crusted
  • Lesions: Dew drops on rose petal appearance
  • Distribution of lesions: predominantly over trunk
  • Pleomorphic rash (NOT Monomorphic): Different stages of rash coexist together simultaneously; this is because lesions appear as Crops
  • Stages → Macule → papules → vesicles → pustules → scabbing

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Hertoghe's sign (Queen Anne's sign)

 

  • It is defined as loss of lateral one third of eye-brows (superciliary madarosis).

 

It is seen in various conditions such as

 

  • Lepromatous leprosy,
  • Atopic dermatitis

 

 

Option B. Hand foot mouth disease: Coxsackie A virus

 

  • Hand foot mouth disease is correctly associated with Coxsackie A virus.
  • It is a common viral illness that usually affects infants and children younger than 5 years old and presents with sores in the mouth and a rash on the hands and feet.

 

Option C. Eczema herpeticum: Kaposi varicelliform eruption:

 

  • A common viral skin infection known as eczema herpeticum or Kaposi varicelliform eruption causes localised or mild vesicular eruptions in people who already have a skin condition (most commonly in atopic dermatitis).
  • Defective skin barrier → acute disseminated cutaneous HSV I infection
  • e.g., in patients with atopic eczema, darier disease or Sezary syndrome
  • Umbilicated Vesiculo pustules → rupture to form punched out erosions covered by hemorrhagic crusts

 

 

The implicated viruses in Eczema herpeticum are:

 

  • HSV-1 (most common)
  • HSV-2
  • VZV
  • Coxsackie A6 and A16 (eczema coxsackium)
  • Vaccinia (eczema vaccinatum)
    • Kaposi varicelliform eruption presents with a high fever and widely disseminated, potentially hemorrhagic vesicles.
    • The skin is painful and generally erythematous.
    • In 4 to 5 days, the fever goes down, and some permanent scarring remains after the pustules crust over and heal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chickenpox is caused by the varicella-zoster virus, not herpes simplex virus type 2.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 25.24- 25.25, 25.38-25.42

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1408

questions.text: What are the diseases / malignancies associated with the virus which is implicated in causing Oral Hairy Leukoplakia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All of the above.

 

Option D.

 

  • Oral Hairy Leukoplakia is due to the reactivation of Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) infection.
  • Oral Hairy Leukoplakia: Manifests as a White corrugated plaque over the lateral border of the tongue in an HIV-infected patient which cannot be rubbed off.

 

 

Diseases associated with EBV infection are:

 

  • Glandular fever
  • Maculopapular rash triggered by ampicillin

 

Malignancies associated with EBV infection are:

 

  • Burkitt's Lymphoma
  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma
  • EBV-associated lymphoproliferative disease
  • Age-related EBV-associated B-cell lymphoma

 

Treatment: HAART

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Epstein-Barr virus is associated with multiple diseases, including Oral Hairy Leukoplakia, Burkitt's lymphoma, glandular fever, and nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page nos 25.33-25.34, Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1416

questions.text: A 10-year-old child develops the following lesions over the face. All the following statements are correct about this disease except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. RNA virus is a causative agent.

 

Option B.

 

The above image shows shiny, pearly white, umbilicated papules which are suggestive of molluscum contagiosum. It’s a DNA virus (NOT RNA)

 

  • It is mainly caused by: Pox virus which is a DNA virus
  • Virus: Molluscum Contagiosum, Virus (MCV).
  • MCV-l → Children → Face (Not seen over palms & soles) (Option D)
  • MCV-2 → Adults producing lesions over → Genitals
  • Transmission: Skin to skin contact.

 

Explanation:

 

Option C: Pseudo-Koebner phenomenon: New lesions develop along the line of trauma due to Autoinoculation.

 

  • Sexually transmitted molluscum contagiosum may be present over the genital area.
  • Microscopic examination of the lesions shows eosinophilic inclusions called Henderson-Patterson bodies.

 

Treatment

 

  • Usually, it is self-limiting and will disappear by itself. Thus, There is no need for treatment
  • Destruction with cantharidin, trichloroacetic acid, diluted liquefied phenol, or surgical removal are a few options.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Molluscum contagiosum is a skin condition caused by a DNA virus, and understand its common presentations and methods of transmission, with a special note that it is not caused by an RNA virus.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I

questions.text: A 9-month-old child is brought by mother with rash as shown in the following picture. Three days ago, she took her to the emergency after the girl spiked a fever to 104 degrees Fahrenheit and had a seizure at home. Her work-up was normal, and she was sent home with acetaminophen and fluids. This morning the child developed a rash on her trunk, which her mother believes is spreading to involve arms and legs. On examination, palate had red papules. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D.  Roseola infantum

 

Option D. 

 

Roseola infantum

 

  • It is the most common exanthematic fever in children under the age of 2 years, caused by Human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) 
  • Lack of symptoms during the febrile phase and the appearance of the eruption as the fever subsides is suggestive of Roseola
  • Manifests as a rosy rash on trunk & neck after 3 days of high fevers; it may later spread to the arms, face and legs.
  • It is a self-limited disease requiring no treatment.
  • Nagayama spots which are red papules over the palate are pathognomonic. Cervical and occipital lymph nodes are usually enlarged.

Clinical confusion with rubella or measles is not uncommon.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Varicella presents as a vesicular eruption over erythematous base, not as a maculopapular rash as given in this case scenario.

 

Option B: Erythema infectiosum / 5th Disease:

 

  • Caused by Human Parvovirus B19.
  • Slapped cheek appearance can be seen.

 

 

Option C: Measles (RUBEOLA):

 

  • Maculopapular rash begins at the hairline, then involves the face and upper neck. Later involves extremities.
  • Fever, running nose and congested eyes.
  • Infectivity period → 4 days Before ←RASH → 5 Days after.
  • Most characteristic Feature → Koplik's Spots [opposite to lower 2nd molar]

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The classic presentation of Roseola infantum is a high fever that resolves followed by a rash that starts on the trunk and spreads to the extremities in a young child.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th editionPage nos 25.34-25.35

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1420

Deep palmoplantar warts are also called as Myrmecia warts

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding Warts and its management except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cryotherapy is a painless procedure

 

Option D.

 

The main disadvantage of Cryotherapy / Freezing is pain.

 

Cryogun has the freezing agent:

 

 

Below image depicts Cryotherapy being administered:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Verruca vulgaris or common wart is most commonly caused by human papillomavirus-2 (HPV-2) but is also related to types 1, 4, 27, and 57.

 

Below image depicts Verruca vulgaris:

 

 

  • Common warts typically have no symptoms.
  • They appear as firm papules with a rough horny surface and exhibit acanthosis, hyperkeratosis, and papillomatosis.
  • The hands, fingers, and knees of young children are the areas that are most frequently affected.
  • Pseudo-Koebner phenomenon may be observed.

 

Option B: Deep palmoplantar warts are also called Myrmecia warts.

 

  • It is usually caused by human papillomavirus-1 (HPV-1).
  • The superficial form of plantar warts is called mosaic warts which are caused by HPV-2.

 

Below image depicts Plantar warts

 

 

Various types of warts and their clinical features:

 

  • Verrucous warts present as asymptomatic skin-coloured papules and plaques with rough surfaces.
  • Filiform warts are finger-like projections.

 

 

  • Verruca Plana are flat surfaced lesions and hence the name. They are mainly due to HPV-3 and - 10.

 

 

Option C: Anogenital Warts are most commonly caused by human papillomavirus 6 (HPV-6 > HPV-11).

 

 

Educational Objective: 

Cryotherapy:

 

  • A doctor administers this treatment.
  • Liquid nitrogen, carbon dioxide snow, and dimethyl ether can all cause thermal injury to the skin.
  • The coldest freeze is produced by liquid nitrogen, which is frequently employed in practice.
  • A cotton wool bud or a cryospray is used to apply it until a rim of iced tissue forms around the wart (visible as a white discoloration).
  • Depending on the size and location of the wart, the freezing is maintained for 5 to 30 seconds.
  • With freezing times under 30 seconds, scarring is unlikely.
  • Cryotherapy is safer than imiquimod, podophyllin, and podofilox, which are teratogenic& so contraindicated during pregnancy.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th editionPage no 25.43, 25.47, 25.48, 25.52

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no1214

questions.text: Child presents with sores in the mouth and a rash on the hands and feet as shown in the image below. What is the causative organism for it?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Coxsackie virus A16

 

Option A.

 

This case scenario hints at hand-foot-and-mouth disease.

 

Etiology: Coxsackie A6, Enterovirus 71

 

Lesions: Papulovesicular lesions.

 

Sites: Present on palms, soles, oral cavity and the buttocks.

 

  • It is common in children.

  • Spread is by droplets or faecal contamination.

  • It appears as painful vesicles that may turn ulcerative in the oral cavity and as tiny, tense blisters with surrounding erythema on the extremities.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Pox virus:

 

  • Poxviruses cause diseases such as smallpox and molluscum contagiosum, which are characterized by distinct lesions but not the oral sores and hand-foot rash combination seen in HFMD.

 

Option C. Herpes virus:

 

  • While certain herpes viruses can cause oral lesions (like HSV-1) and others can cause systemic symptoms (like varicella-zoster virus), they do not typically cause the hand-foot-mouth disease pattern.

 

Option D. Human papillomavirus (HPV):

 

  • HPV causes warts and is not typically associated with the systemic presentation of hand, foot, and mouth disease with oral sores.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Coxsackie virus A16 is the causative organism of hand, foot, and mouth disease, characterized by oral sores and a rash on the hands and feet.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Page no 117.6

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no1426

It is commonly caused by herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1)

questions.text: This 37-year-old woman developed these grouped vesicles near her lips after developing fever. All of the following statements are true about this disease EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Once disease is treated with antivirals, recurrences are uncommon

 

Option D.

 

  • Recurrent herpetic lesions (Option D) are very common & are vesicular and ulcerative and tend to occur in the same region.

 

Herpes labialis

 

  • It is also known as a cold sore(option A) is characterised by clusters of numerous vesicles around the lips.
  • Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) (Option C) and type 2 are rarely responsible for its occurrence (HSV-2)
  • Herpes can be treated with Foscarnet (Option B) or cidofovir if acyclovir resistance develops in a patient with recurrent Herpes labialis. They act on viral DNA polymerases thus blocking DNA replication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Herpes labialis, caused by HSV-1, can be treated with antivirals like acyclovir and foscarnet for resistant cases, but despite treatment, recurrences are common due to the latent nature of the virus.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Page no 25.12, 25.17-19, 25.20

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1402

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding Herpes zoster (Shingles)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Maculopapular rash is seen

 

Option B.

 

Herpes zoster:

 

  • A maculopapular rash is not seen in zoster (shingles).

  • Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia (Option A) for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution.

  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved(Option D)

  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.

  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.

  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia (Option C). Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

  • Painful zoster infections in adults

  • Facial zoster at any age

  • Immunocompromised

 

Complications:

 

  • The commonest and most intractablecomplication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia.

  • It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster.

  • Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve (Option C) is involved.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presentation of herpes zoster (shingles) is a vesicular rash within a single dermatome and recognize the virus's ability to remain latent in the dorsal root ganglia, with potential complications including post-herpetic neuralgia, especially with trigeminal nerve involvement.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th editionPage nos 4.13, 25.27-25.28

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th EditionPage no 106

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no1412

questions.text: Slapped cheek appearance is associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Erythema infectiosum

 

Option A:

 

Erythema infectiosum

 

It is also known as Fifth disease or "slapped cheek" syndrome, is characterized by the appearance of a bright red rash on the cheeks.

 

 

  • It is a childhood illness caused by Parvovirus B19.
  • This distinctive facial rash gives the appearance as if the child has been slapped on the cheeks, hence the name.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Herpes zoster

 

  • Herpes zoster, also known as shingles, is caused by the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus and presents as a painful rash with blisters in a dermatomal fashion, usually in a band on one side of the body or face.

 

 

  • It does not cause the slapped cheek appearance.

 

Option C: Kaposi sarcoma

 

  • Kaposi sarcoma is a type of cancer that forms in the lining of blood and lymph vessels.

 

 

  • It is associated with HHV 8 infection.
  • The lesions are typically red or purple and can occur anywhere on the body, including the skin and internal organs, not presenting as a slapped cheek rash.

 

Option D: Molluscum contagiosum

 

  • Molluscum contagiosum is a viral skin infection that causes raised, umbilicated papules or nodules on the skin.

 

 

  • These are not associated with the slapped cheek appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Erythema infectiosum (Fifth disease) is identified by its classic clinical presentation of a "slapped cheek" rash on the face, which is a hallmark sign of this viral illness in children.
  • It's important for medical students and clinicians to recognize this distinctive rash for proper diagnosis and reassurance, as this condition is usually self-limiting and requires no specific treatment beyond symptomatic relief.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no25.66

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1430

choices.text: Dengue (during febrile phase)

questions.text: Which of the following does not present with maculopapular rash?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Zoster (shingles)

 

Option A.

 

A maculopapular rash is not seen in zoster (shingles).

 

  • Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution as shown in the image below.
     

 

Herpes zoster:

 

  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

  1. Painful zoster infections in adults
  2. Facial zoster at any age
  3. Immunocompromised

 

The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Rubella: Presents with a maculopapular rash as shown in the image below, which consists of minute, discrete macules.
 

 

The rash appears within 24 hours of onset of prodromal symptoms.

 

Rubella virus is a RNA virus which belongs to Togaviridae family.

 

Option C: Dengue (during febrile phase): Dengue fever can present with a maculopapular rash during its febrile phase.

 

Option D: Measles: Measles is characterized by fever and a maculopapular skin rash, which is accompanied by immune clearance of measles virus (MV)-infected cells

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Zoster (shingles) does not present with a maculopapular rash but rather with a painful, vesicular rash in a dermatomal distribution.
  • In contrast, rubella, dengue during the febrile phase, and measles are classic causes of maculopapular rashes.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no. 4.13, 25.27-25.28
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106

questions.text: Rubella virus belongs to which family?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Togaviridae

 

Option D. 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When classifying viruses, it is important to identify the correct family based on the virus's genome type, envelope presence, and disease association.
  • The rubella virus is classified under the Togaviridae family due to its positive-sense single-stranded RNA genome and association with rubella disease.

questions.text: Match the Viral organisms/infections in Column A with its Histopathological characteristic features in Column B:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-b, 2-c, 3-a

 

Option A.

 

The correct match between the Viral organisms /infections in Column A with its Histopathological characteristic features in Column B

  1. CMV (Cytomegalovirus) has the characteristic Owl's eye inclusion bodies (a), which are large intranuclear inclusions surrounded by a clear halo, seen in cells infected with CMV.

questions.text: A child presents with multiple skin lesions over the inner thigh and genital areas. Some lesions have central umbilication. The representative of the histology of the lesion is shown below. What would be found on biopsy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Henderson-Patterson bodies

 

Option B:

 

  • They are also known as molluscum bodies, are pathognomonic for Molluscum contagiosum, which is characterized by skin lesions with a central umbilication, as described in the clinical presentation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Donovan bodies

 

  • They are intracytoplasmic inclusions seen in granuloma inguinale caused by Klebsiella granulomatis.
  • These are not associated with umbilicated skin lesions.

 

Option C: Koilocytes

 

  • They are indicative of HPV infection and are typically associated with changes in the skin and mucous membranes that do not usually present with umbilicated lesions.

 

Option D: Tzanck cells

 

  • They are Acantholytic cells seen in vesiculobullous disorders like pemphigus and herpes infections, such as herpes simplex and varicella-zoster virus, which typically present with vesicular lesions rather than umbilicated nodules.

 

 

Some important findings on Tzanck smear are as follows:

 

 

Image: Tzanck smear, showing multinucleated giant cells in center

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Henderson-Patterson bodies on biopsy is diagnostic for Molluscum contagiosum, a viral skin infection that presents with characteristic central umbilication.
  • Recognizing the histopathological features of common skin lesions is essential for accurate diagnosis and management in dermatology.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 25.13

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1440

choices.text: Hand Foot Mouth Disease (HFMD)

questions.text: Vesicular rash is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD)

 

Option B:

 

  • HFMD is characterized by a vesicular rash on the hands, feet, and oral cavity.
     

 

  • It is a common viral illness usually caused by Coxsackievirus and is seen mostly in children.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Dengue.

 

  • Dengue fever typically presents with high fever, headache, severe muscle and joint pain, and a rash.
  • The rash associated with dengue fever is not typically vesicular but can be morbilliform (measles-like).

 

Option C: Roseola infantum–

 

  • Also known as sixth disease and caused by human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6), Roseola presents with a sudden high fever that lasts for several days, followed by a rash as the fever subsides.
  • The rash is not vesicular but rather maculopapular.

 

Option D: Zika virus–

 

  • The Zika virus can cause fever, rash, joint pain, and red eyes, but the rash associated with Zika is not vesicular.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When assessing a patient with a vesicular rash, it is essential to consider HFMD, especially in children.
  • This disease presents with characteristic vesicles on the hands, feet, and mouth and is often associated with fever and malaise.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 25.81

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1425

questions.text: An elderly person presented with lesions as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Herpes zoster.

 

Option C:

 

  • Herpes zoster, also known as shingles, is caused by the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus and presents with painful, grouped vesicles on an erythematous base, following a dermatomal distribution, as shown in the image.
  • This pattern is characteristic of herpes zoster.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Chickenpox.

 

  • Chickenpox, caused by the varicella-zoster virus, typically presents with a pruritic, vesicular rash that starts on the face and trunk and spreads to the rest of the body.
  • The lesions appear in crops and are at different stages of healing.
  • The rash in the image does not display this typical distribution or the various stages of healing.

 

Option B: Contact dermatitis

 

  • Contact dermatitis is an inflammatory skin condition caused by contact with a substance that triggers an allergic or irritant response.
  • It presents with erythema, edema, and sometimes vesicles, but these are not typically in a dermatomal distribution.

 

Option D: Lichen planus.

 

  • Lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory condition of the skin and mucous membranes.
  • It presents with pruritic, flat-topped, violaceous papules and plaques with fine white lines (Wickham's striae) on the surface.

 

 

  • The rash in the image does not exhibit these features.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Herpes zoster can be identified by its distinctive clustered vesicular eruption within a single dermatome, which is typically unilateral and does not cross the midline.
  • This presentation is especially common in elderly or immunocompromised individuals due to the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no25.27

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 4, 1412

questions.text: HIV patient with following mucosal lesion came for consultation to a dermatology OPD. What can be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Kaposi sarcoma

 

Option B:

 

  • This is based on the clinical presentation and histopathological findings provided.
  • Kaposi's sarcoma is characterized by multiple, firm, non-tender, violaceous plaques and is associated with human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8).
  • The presence of leukopenia and a low CD4 count further supports the diagnosis of an HIV-infected individual.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Basal cell carcinoma

 

  • It usually presents as a pearly nodular lesion with telangiectasia and rarely occurs in the oral cavity.

 

Option C: Melanoma in the oral cavity is rare and typically presents as a rapidly enlarging dark lesion.

 

Option D: Squamous cell carcinoma

 

  • It tends to present as an ulcerative lesion with indurated margins and can be more common in the oral cavity but does not match the description of firm, violaceous plaques.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When an HIV patient presents with firm, violaceous plaques in the oral cavity and skin, Kaposi's sarcoma should be suspected.
  • Diagnosis can be confirmed with a biopsy showing spindle-cell neoplasm positive for CD34 and HHV-8.
  • Treatment includes antiretroviral therapy and, if necessary, chemotherapy.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 25.37

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 32, 2022

choices.text: Disseminated molluscum contagiosum

questions.text: An adult female HIV patient with hilar lymphadenopathy & lung infiltration comes to you with these lesions over body as shown. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Disseminated histoplasmosis

 

Option B.

 

  • The description of the skin lesions as multiple, discrete, skin-colored, umbilicated papules, along with systemic symptoms like hilar lymphadenopathy and lung infiltration in an HIV patient, are suggestive of disseminated histoplasmosis.
  • The histopathology findings of granulomatous inflammation and parasitized macrophages with small round organisms with a clear halocan be seen in histoplasmosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cryptococcus

 

  • This typically presents with cutaneous lesions in HIV patients, they are associated withumbilicated papules.
  • Cryptococcal infections more commonly manifest as meningitis or disseminated disease with cutaneous lesions that can be molluscum-like, but other systemic signs would be expected.

 

Option C. Disseminated molluscum contagiosum

 

  • This can present with umbilicated papules in immunocompromised patients.
  • However, the presence of systemic symptomsis not consistent with molluscum contagiosum.

 

Option D. Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia / Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP):

 

  • This does not typically present with cutaneous manifestations.
  • It presents with respiratory symptoms and is diagnosed with chest imaging and identification of the organism in respiratory specimens, not skin lesions.

 

Diseases which can manifest with umbilicated papules over skin surface:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To differentiate between various opportunistic infections in HIV patients, focusing on their cutaneous manifestations, systemic involvement, and specific histopathological findings.
  • Skin lesions in HIV patients can indicate systemic opportunistic infections, and the clinical presentation combined with histopathology is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 31.26

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1352

choices.text: Anterior nerve roots are more commonly involved
Mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved
The lesions are not infectious
Trigeminal dermatome is most commonly affected

questions.text: What is correct regarding the diagnosis based on the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved

 

Option B.

 

  • The above image shows confluent, red, pustular lesions in a single dermatome suggestive of herpes zoster or shingles.
  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.

 

Varicella-zoster virus (VZV)

 

  • This is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia (NOT Anterior nerve roots Option A) for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution as shown in the image below.

 

 

Varicella-zoster virus (VZV)

 

  • It is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution.

 

Herpes zoster:

 

  • Thoracic dermatome is most commonly affected (NOT Trigeminal). (Option D)
  • The rash is restricted to a dermatome, but sometimes a few chickenpoxtype lesions can be found elsewhere. The lesions are infectious. (Option C)
  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection, but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

  1. Painful zoster infections in adults
  2. Facial zoster at any age
  3. Immunocompromised

 

Complications:

 

  • The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia.
  • It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster.
  • Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.
     

Educational Objective:

 

  • Herpes zoster, commonly involves reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus within the dorsal root ganglion, leading to painful cutaneous eruptions that can affect mucous membranes within the involved dermatomes.
  • Herpes zoster lesions are infectious, particularly to those who are not immune to varicella-zoster virus, and thoracic dermatome is the most frequently affected area.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no. 25.27-25.28

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 4.13

choices.text: Bacterial meningitis
Hand foot and mouth disease
Tubercular meningitis

questions.text: A child was admitted with complaints of fever, neck rigidity (meningitis features) with associated oral erosions and skin manifestations as shown in the picture. CSF analysis show normal glucose, proteins and lymphocytes increased. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Herpes simplex infection

 

Option D.

 

  • Herpes simplex virus (HSV) can cause meningitis, especially HSV-2.
  • The presence of oral erosions and skin lesions which are grouped vesicles, resembling herpetic vesicles, alongside signs of meningitis, and CSF analysis showing normal glucose, normal protein, and increased lymphocytes is indicative of HSV infection, not bacterial or tubercular meningitis.

 

Explanation

 

Option A. Bacterial meningitis

 

  • This typically presents with high fever, neck rigidity, and altered mental status.
  • CSF analysis often shows elevated white cells (usually neutrophils), low glucose, and high proteins, which is not the case here.

 

Option B. Hand, foot, and mouth disease

 

  • It is usually caused by Coxsackievirus and primarily affects children.
  • It presents with oral ulcers and a rash on the hands and feet, but it is not commonly associated with meningitis.

 

Option C. Tubercular meningitis

 

  • It would generally present with a chronic course of fever and neck rigidity.
  • CSF analysis in tubercular meningitis often shows low glucose, elevated proteins, and lymphocytosis, which does not align with the findings presented.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To diagnose herpes simplex infection in a pediatric patient presenting with fever, neck rigidity, oral erosions, characteristic skin manifestations, and CSF findings consistent with viral meningitis.
  • The recognition of oral and skin lesions typical of herpes simplex is crucial in differentiating it from other causes of meningitis.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 25.16

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1368

choices.text: Fixed Drug Eruption
Erythema infectiosum
Measles

questions.text: A 6-month-old male child experienced an abrupt high-grade fever lasting several days, followed by its sudden cessation. After the fever resolved, he developed a rash that began on his trunk and then spread to his arms and legs as shown in the image below. The child also had a brief febrile seizure during the period of high fever. The rash is not pruritic and the child is otherwise well-appearing. Based on this clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Roseola Infantum

 

Option D.

 

  • Roseola, caused by Human Herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6), commonly presents in infants with high-grade fever that resolves abruptly followed by a characteristic rash that starts on the trunk and then spreads to the extremities.
  • The history of a febrile seizure is also supportive of Roseola, as such seizures can occur during the febrile phase of the illness.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fixed Drug Eruption

 

  • It typically presents as well-demarcated, round, reddish-brown plaques that recur at the same site with the re-administration of the offending drug.
  • This is unlikely in a 6-month-old infant who likely has not had multiple drug exposures.

 

Option B. Erythema Infectiosum

 

  • It is also known as fifth disease, is caused by Parvovirus B19 and typically presents with a "slapped cheek" facial rash followed by a lacy, reticulated body rash.

 

 

  • It does not typically present with high fever or febrile seizures.

 

Option C. Measles

 

  • It typically starts with a high fever, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis, followed by a spreading rash from the face to the rest of the body, along with Koplik's spots inside the mouth.

 

 

  • The clinical presentation in the question does not mention these features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Diagnose Roseola based on the classic clinical triad of high-grade fever, subsequent rash, and potential febrile seizure in a young infant.
  • The sequence is fever followed by rash (after fever subsides), in the absence of other systemic symptoms, is key to identifying Roseola over other pediatric exanthems.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 25.34

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1420

choices.text: Epstein Barr Virus (EBV)
Human Herpes Virus (HHV7)

questions.text: An immunocompromised individual presents with a corrugated white lesion on the side of the tongue as shown in the image below, which does not wipe off. The most likely causative agent is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Epstein Barr Virus (EBV)

 

Option B.

 

  • It is known to cause oral hairy Leukoplakia, an EBV-induced lesion typically occurring in immunocompromised individuals.
  • The lesion appears as a white, corrugated (or hairy) patch that cannot be wiped off, which matches the presentation in the image.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Candida

 

  • It typically causes oral thrush, which presents as white plaques that can be wiped off, unlike the corrugated lesion shown in the image.

 

Option C. Human Herpes Virus (HHV7)

 

  • This is not commonly associated with oral lesions in immunocompromised patients.
  • HHV-7 more often reactivates to cause roseola in infants or is asymptomatic in adults.

 

Option D. Human Herpes Virus 8 (HHV8)

 

  • This is associated with Kaposi's sarcoma, not corrugated white oral lesions.
  • Kaposi's sarcoma typically presents as red or purple lesions in the oral cavity or on the skin.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Oral hairy Leukoplakia in immunocompromised patients and understand its association with EBV. Recognizing that these lesions do not wipe off is a key diagnostic feature distinguishing them from other conditions like candidiasis.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 33.31

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1370

choices.text: She is susceptible to zoster.
She is susceptible to chickenpox.
She is immune to zoster.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida is living with her nephew, who has recently developed varicella. She has no history of varicella exposure or vaccination, and serological testing reveals that she is not immune to the varicella-zoster virus (VZV). Based on this information, which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. She is susceptible to chickenpox.

 

Option B.

 

Varicella:

 

The absence of antibodies against VZV indicates that the patient is susceptible to primary VZV infection, commonly known as chickenpox.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. is Incorrect because zoster, or shingles, occurs in individuals who have had chickenpox in the past and the virus reactivates. Since the patient has never had chickenpox, she is not at risk for zoster until she has had a primary VZV infection.

 

Option C. is Incorrect. Immunity to zoster implies that the patient has had a prior infection with VZV, which is not the case here as evidenced by the negative antibody test.

 

Option D. is Incorrect because the negative varicella antibody test indicates that the patient does not have immunity to chickenpox.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The absence of varicella antibodies in an individual with no past history of infection or vaccination indicates susceptibility to primary varicella-zoster virus infection, which presents as chickenpox.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 25.25

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1408

choices.text: Herpangina
Molluscum contagiosum
Impetigo

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the clinic with painful vesicles on his lip that erupted two days after he felt a tingling sensation in the area. He has had similar episodes in the past, usually during periods of stress or sun exposure. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Herpes labialis

 

Option D:

 

Herpes labialis, based on the clinical presentation and the recurrent nature of the lesions described in the patient's history.

 

  • This is commonly known as cold sores, is caused by the herpes simplex virus, typically type 1 (HSV-1).
  • It presents with recurrent painful vesicles on the lips that often follow a prodromal period of tingling or itching.
  • The patient's history of similar recurrent episodes triggered by stress or sun exposure, along with the clinical presentation, strongly suggests herpes labialis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Herpangina

 

  • This is caused by the Coxsackie virus and is characterized by small, painful vesicles and ulcers on the posterior oropharynx, not on the lips.
     

 

  • Patients often present with a sore throat, fever, and malaise, which are not described in this vignette.

 

Option B. Molluscum contagiosum

 

  • It presents with small, flesh-colored, dome-shaped papules with a central umbilication, typically not painful, caused by a poxvirus infection.

 

 

  • This condition does not match the description of painful lip vesicles that are recurrent and associated with prodromal symptoms.

 

Option C. Impetigo

 

  • This is a superficial skin infection characterized by honey-coloredcrusts and can be caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus species.

 

 

  • While it can affect the face, the presence of grouped vesicles with a history of recurrence and a tingling prodrome is more suggestive of herpes labialis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The clinical presentation of herpes labialis, includes the characteristic painful vesicles on the lips that often recur, triggered by factors such as stress or sun exposure.
  • Understanding the etiology and triggers is crucial for appropriate management and counselling of patients with recurrent herpes labialis.

 

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Page no 25.12, 25.17-19, 25.20

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1402
